title: William Dyke
text:
William D. "Bill" Dyke (April 25, 1930March 10, 2016) was an American lawyer, judge, and politician. He was a two-term <a href="mayor">mayor</a> of <a href="Madison%2C%20Wisconsin">Madison, Wisconsin</a> from 1969 to 1973 and ran for <a href="Vice%20President%20of%20the%20United%20States">Vice President of the United States</a> on the <a href="American%20Independent%20Party">American Independent Party</a> <a href="Ticket%20%28politics%29">ticket</a> with presidential candidate <a href="Lester%20Maddox">Lester Maddox</a> in <a href="U.S.%20presidential%20election%2C%201976">1976</a>. From 1996 until two months before his death, in 2016, he served as a <a href="Wisconsin%20circuit%20courts">Wisconsin Circuit Court</a> Judge in <a href="Iowa%20County%2C%20Wisconsin">Iowa County, Wisconsin</a>, he was Chief Judge of the 7th Judicial Administrative District from 2007 to 2013.
Early life.
Dyke received his bachelor's degree from <a href="DePauw%20University">DePauw University</a> in <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a>. While completing his degree at the <a href="University%20of%20Wisconsin%20Law%20School">University of Wisconsin Law School</a>, he hosted "Circus 3", a local children's television program on <a href="WISC-TV">WISC-TV</a>. He also moderated "Face the State", a local political news program modeled after the nationally televised "<a href="Face%20the%20Nation">Face the Nation</a>". The program included interviews with <a href="Richard%20Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>, <a href="Hubert%20H.%20Humphrey">Hubert Humphrey</a>, <a href="Gerald%20Ford">Gerald Ford</a>, <a href="John%20F.%20Kennedy">John F. Kennedy</a> and other prominent politicians.
Political career.
Dyke was a two-term <a href="mayor">mayor</a> of <a href="Madison%2C%20Wisconsin">Madison, Wisconsin</a> from 1969 to 1973. His tenure as mayor is considered a colorful and often controversial part of Madison's history. Dyke presided over Madison during the most turbulent era in the city's history, highlighted by the <a href="Sterling%20Hall%20bombing">Sterling Hall bombing</a> and subsequent clashes with student uprisings. One of those student activists, <a href="Paul%20Soglin">Paul Soglin</a>, defeated Dyke's attempt for re-election in 1973. Undeterred, Dyke ran as the Republican nominee for governor in 1974, losing to Democrat <a href="Patrick%20Lucey">Patrick Lucey</a>.
A <a href="conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">conservative</a> <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a>, Dyke briefly left the party in <a href="1976%20United%20States%20presidential%20election">1976</a> to join Lester Maddox's American Independent Party presidential ticket as the vice presidential nominee; however, he disavowed Maddox's <a href="Segregation%20in%20the%20United%20States">segregationist</a> views. Maddox and Dyke won 170,274 votes in the general election (or 0.21% of votes).
Post-political career.
Following the end of his political career, Dyke opened a general contracting business in <a href="Mount%20Horeb%2C%20Wisconsin">Mount Horeb</a>, Wisconsin, and bred <a href="horse">horse</a>s. He also worked as a family mediation lawyer in <a href="Mineral%20Point%2C%20Wisconsin">Mineral Point</a>, Wisconsin.
On December 3, 1996, <a href="Governor%20of%20Wisconsin">Governor</a> <a href="Tommy%20Thompson">Tommy Thompson</a> appointed Dyke to the circuit court vacancy in <a href="Iowa%20County%2C%20Wisconsin">Iowa County</a>, created by the impending retirement of Judge James P. Fiedler. He was elected to a full term on the court in 1998 and subsequently re-elected in 2004 and 2010. He later was selected as the chief judge of the 7th Judicial Administrative District by the <a href="Wisconsin%20Supreme%20Court">Wisconsin Supreme Court</a>, and served the maximum of three two-year terms in that role. Dyke left the bench in January 2016, and died of pancreatic cancer in a Dodgeville, WI nursing home two months later.
Dyke illustrated the children's book "The General's Hat, or Why the Bell Tower Stopped Working", a tale written by Kay Price about two mice who get on the same ship with General <a href="Ulysses%20S.%20Grant">Ulysses S. Grant</a> on his travels to <a href="Galena%2C%20Illinois">Galena</a>, <a href="Illinois">Illinois</a>.
